title: Yet Another MEX Problem
statementHtml:
We define the weight of an array bb consisting of mm non-negative integers as the number of indices ii (1≤i≤m1≤i≤m) satisfying bi>mex(b)bi>mex⁡(b). Here, mex(b)mex⁡(b) denotes the minimum excluded (MEX)∗∗ of the integers in bb.

You are given an array aa consisting of nn non-negative integers. For its subarray†† [al,al+1,…,ar][al,al+1,…,ar], we denote the weight of the subarray as w(l,r)w(l,r).

For every 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, you have to find the maximum weight over all subarrays of aa ending at index ii. In other words, you have to find max1≤l≤iw(l,i)max1≤l≤iw(l,i) for every 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n.

∗∗The minimum excluded (MEX) of a collection of integers b1,b2,…,bmb1,b2,…,bm is defined as the smallest non-negative integer xx which does not occur in the collection bb.

††An array cc is a subarray of an array aa if cc can be obtained from aa by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤3⋅1051≤n≤3⋅105) — the length of aa.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n) — the elements of aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output nn integers, the ii-th integer denoting the maximum weight over all subarrays of aa ending at index ii, i.e., max1≤l≤iw(l,i)max1≤l≤iw(l,i).
noteHtml:
In the first test case, we have w(1,1)=0w(1,1)=0, because mex([a1])=1mex⁡([a1])=1, and there are no indices satisfying ai>1ai>1.

In the second test case, we can calculate the weight of each subarray [l,r][l,r] by the definition:

  1. w(1,1)=1w(1,1)=1. Thus, max1≤l≤1w(l,1)=1max1≤l≤1w(l,1)=1;
  2. w(1,2)=1w(1,2)=1 and w(2,2)=0w(2,2)=0. Thus, max1≤l≤2w(l,2)=1max1≤l≤2w(l,2)=1;
  3. w(1,3)=2w(1,3)=2 and w(2,3)=w(3,3)=1w(2,3)=w(3,3)=1. Thus, max1≤l≤3w(l,3)=2max1≤l≤3w(l,3)=2;
  4. w(1,4)=2w(1,4)=2, w(2,4)=w(3,4)=1w(2,4)=w(3,4)=1, and w(4,4)=0w(4,4)=0. Thus, max1≤l≤4w(l,4)=2max1≤l≤4w(l,4)=2;
  5. w(1,5)=0w(1,5)=0, w(2,5)=w(3,5)=1w(2,5)=w(3,5)=1, and w(4,5)=0,w(5,5)=1w(4,5)=0,w(5,5)=1. Thus, max1≤l≤5w(l,5)=1max1≤l≤5w(l,5)=1.

For example, w(1,4)=2w(1,4)=2 because mex([a1,a2,a3,a4])=1mex⁡([a1,a2,a3,a4])=1, and there are two indices satisfying ai>1ai>1 in the subarray: 11 and 33.
tutorialHtml:
Let's calculate the weight of an array without calculating its mex: For each integer x that does not occur in the array, calculate the number of elements ai>x and compare it to the answer. Note that we have weakened the conditions from x being the mex to x not occurring. This will not change the answer because the answer is always maximized when x is equal to the mex.

Then, to calculate max1≤l≤rw(l,r), we can iterate over all integers x that 0≤x≤n, find its last occurrence p (p=0 if it never occurred), and use this x to calculate w(p+1,r) and compare it to the answer. That is, the number of integers i that p<i≤r and ap>x.

Let's iterate over all integers r and use a segment tree to maintain the answer bx for each x. Initially bx=0. When you add 1 to r and add a new integer ar to the array, we should set bar=0 and then increase bi by 1 for 0≤i<ar. And then the maximum of array b will be the answer.

The time complexity is O(nlogn).
